Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structural and Electronic Contributions to Reactivity in Peroxomanganese(III) Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program supports the CAREER award of Professor Timothy Jackson at the University of Kansas who performs research to understand the mechanisms of Manganese (Mn) enzymes and improve synthetic catalysts that catalyze a diverse array of reactions including the detoxification of reactive oxygen species in humans, the degradation of aromatics in bacteria and fungi, and the conversion of nucleotides to deoxynucleotides in pathogens. Peroxomanganese(III) (MnIII-O2) adducts have been proposed as crucial intermediates in these biological and synthetic systems. Professor Jackson will use spectroscopic and computational tools to define the structural, electronic, magnetic, and reactivity properties of peroxomanganese (III) intermediates supported by ligands relevant to biological and synthetic systems. This work will advance our understanding of Mn enzymes and aid in the development of Mn oxidation catalysts.

With the support of the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Timothy Jackson will perform research that can lead to better catalyst design and improved understanding of enzymes. This can ultimately translate into improved diagnostic and therapeutic medicinal agents. The outreach program is very creative and extremely well organized and planned. The proposed outreach activities will provide an opportunity for 100 middle school girls, minorities, and those from economically-disadvantaged backgrounds to explore how electromagnetic radiation (light) affects their daily lives. To integrate research and education experiences, graduate and undergraduate students will serve as camp mentors. The summer camps should have a direct and positive impact on underrepresented groups in science at the important age of middle school students. The development of a camp website with pedagogical videos will provide broad dissemination of camp materials. Some of the initial research data have already been presented in peer-reviewed journals and at professional meetings.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The transition metal manganese is essential to many organisms, including humans. Examples of the biological roles of manganese include involvement in oxidative stress response, DNA biosynthesis, and the formation of oxygen in plants. In these reactions, manganese centers react with oxygen and its derivatives, often forming intermediates known as manganese-peroxo species. There is also significant interest in understanding manganese-peroxo species in order to develop new catalysts for industrially useful reactions. Manganese catalysts have several desirable properties; earth abundance, affordability, and relatively low toxicity. However, a better understanding of the chemical reactivity of manganese-peroxo species is necessary in order to design more efficacious catalysts.

The research goal of this project was to provide new insights into the physical properties and chemical reactivity of manganese-peroxo species. We successfully prepared a series of manganese-peroxo complexes with systematically altered properties and used both experimental and quantum chemical methods to characterize these complexes. Collectively, these studies allowed us to better understand how the environment of a manganese-peroxo species can control its chemical reactivity. This information is important in rationalizing the diverse reactivity of manganese-peroxo species observed in nature. We were also able to identify conditions under which manganese-peroxo species could be converted by oxygen-oxygen bond cleavage events to give manganese-oxo species. Oxygen-oxygen bond cleavage reactions are central to many biological and industrially important processes.

The educational goal of this project resulted in the development of two new courses – a freshman-level course focused on the development of chemical concepts in the early 20th century, and a junior/sophomore-level course on metals in biology. The latter course included an emphasis on independent learning and culminated in having students develop and defend an original research proposal. In addition, this project led to several University and public outreach efforts highlighting the role of chemical principles in modern cooking techniques.


Last Modified: 05/19/2017
Modified by: Timothy Jackson
